ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Survey of integral calculus: approximating areas under curves, techniques for computing many different kinds of integrals, finding areas between curves, volumes of rotation, sequences and series, and polar and parametric equations.
I learned basic calculus 2: complex integrals, parametrics, polar equations, and series & sequences.
I learned Math! Kind of
I learned how to compute integrals, determine series convergence, and use polar and parametric equations.
Calculus 2 and how to struggle effectively
Knowledge of calculus
I learned more about integral calculus

I learned so much!!! I learned how to solve complex math problems, utilize math equations, and was able to internalize and understand tricky math concepts. Not to mention how to complete PSETs, study, and take college level calculus exams! I am very very proud of all that I have learned and all that I have put into this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: super organized across all sections, which is an impressive feat on the administration's part. the explorations were helpful in introducing new material. Peer tutors were amazing and there's a ton of support for student learning in this course - which is awesome. 

Weaknesses: Not really any I can think of. It's a pretty standard course.

This course has a really good support system, with so many professors and office hours and Peer Tutoring hours. One weakness of the course would probably be that each class was different, so some classes would fall behind I think. It all felt so rushed, but I don't know how to improve that.

Weaknesses: it varies depending on the section. The explores do not help and lectures move fast
Strengths: learn math 
Improvement: I would change the explores to due after math class and make it a recap of the lecture with some practice problems rather than it being a preview of the lecture.

This course was pretty average. The strengths definitely lie in the peer tutors. The weaknesses would be that the teachers are so obviously brilliant but the knowledge doesnt necessarily trickle down effectively.
Strength - very consistent work/problem sets, never any confusion about what you have to do for assignments.
Strength was the textbook was pretty good, weakness was that the instructor wasn't good
no noticeable strengths or weaknesses

I had a very hard time learning the material in class. Most of what I learned came from the text book (which I spent HOURS AND HOURS reading), and peer tutoring which I tried to go to every day (shout out to Billy and Erica THEY WERE THE BEST)!! At the beginning I did not get a lot out of class, but later lessons got better and better. Especially as lessons became more interactive and we had more time for group work I started to really enjoying class and learning a lot!

Many of the students in the class had already learned all the topics in high school, while many others were learning concepts for the first time. This made the class dynamic more difficult for all students as some easily understood topics in class and others were lost.

Math 115 is a very well organized course and I felt that all resources provided actually helped me to better understand the material. The problem sets and explorations were helpful and useful aspects of the course. Professor Barnes, to whose office hours I went to, as they fitted well my schedule, is also a major strength of the course as he is very approachable and it is obvious that he is an expert in calculus but also loves it and thus could explain well and in an engaging way any questions I asked him. Although review sessions were a smart idea, only one conducted by Professor Diethorn was useful. She summarized the whole syllabus for the midterm in 2 hours and that is exactly what somebody can expect at a helpful review session. All other review sessions were conducted at a slower and less engaging pace. To solve this issue, all review sessions could be predominantly theoretical. After the theory would be reviewed then separate practice sessions could be conducted, if necessary.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Eh, you're probably taking it for a requirement and it's not bad. Though, the content is pretty cut and dry so I wouldn't recommend taking it for fun necessarily.
I would recommend this course to another student because it's a prerequisite for a lot of things...
Do not take this class unless it is a major requirement. This is not an enjoyable class and how much you learn is entirely dependent on which grad student teacher you get.
Yes math is a great skill to have but if you don't really need it for anything, then find an easier QR to take.
If they needed the class I would recommend it, but probably not as a class to take for the sake of learning unless they were interested in math.
If you need it for a major or youre reallly into math.
- if you have to for a requirement then yes.
No, I do not think it was well-taught and I had to do the majority of learning on my own.
To be completely honest I would not, unless someone was serious about pursuing math. It was so so so hard, at least for me, and I feel like it was especially hard for me as an English non-math major.
